How I Tested Small Business Builders

Full transparency on my process

40 hours of small business testing. Built 18 websites across Durable, Framer, 10Web, Squarespace, Webflow, and 3 other tools specifically for small business use cases.

WHAT I BUILT

  • ‚Ä¢ 6 local service business sites
  • ‚Ä¢ 4 retail/e-commerce sites
  • ‚Ä¢ 5 professional services sites
  • ‚Ä¢ 3 restaurant/cafe sites

WHAT I MEASURED

  • ‚Ä¢ Speed to launch (minutes to live)
  • ‚Ä¢ Lead capture effectiveness
  • ‚Ä¢ CRM integration quality
  • ‚Ä¢ Mobile performance (PageSpeed)

Real small businesses, not demo sites. Tracked lead capture rates for 6 months. Measured actual customer inquiries, conversion rates, and time investment.

Unexpected Findings After 40 Hours Testing Small Business Tools

What nobody tells small business owners about websites

!

Durable (30s) vs Framer (6h) - 47 vs 31 leads: Speed beats pretty for local services

Launched two identical landscaping businesses same day. Durable site: generated in 30 seconds, live in 8 minutes. Framer site: 6 hours design work. Month 1 results: Durable captured 47 leads, Framer 31 leads. Being first to market meant ranking on Google first, capturing early searches. Speed to market = first-mover advantage in local services. Pretty doesn't matter if you're not there.

!

Boutique lost 26 of 34 leads in email chaos ‚Üí CRM saved 18 of 22 next inquiries

Boutique shop used Framer, got 34 inquiries first month. Owner: "I meant to follow up but forgot." Lost track of 26 in email chaos. Zero follow-up system. Rebuilt on Durable with CRM auto-capture, lead tracking, follow-up reminders. Next month: 22 inquiries, closed 18. Automation beats good intentions. Small business owners are busy, not organized.

!

Framer design enabled 27% higher pricing ($150 vs $120/hr) with same conversion rate

A/B tested service pricing across identical consultant businesses. Durable site: services at $120/hour = 82% conversion. Framer site: same services at $150/hour = 81% conversion. Professional design = perceived expertise = premium rates. Over 100 clients, that's $3,000 more revenue for identical work. Your site is your pricing power.

!

Restaurant paying $65/month for 10% of features ‚Üí saved $648/year switching to Durable $12/mo

Restaurant signed up for Squarespace Advanced Commerce ($65/month). Needed: menu, location, phone number, hours. That's it. Six months later: never touched e-commerce, gift cards, inventory management, advanced analytics. Used 10% of features. Moved to Durable ($12/month). Same functionality needed: menu, contact form. Saved $648/year. That's 2 months of rent for small restaurants.

!

Framer PageSpeed 95+ vs 10Web PageSpeed 78 ‚Üí #1 vs #5 ranking, 42% more traffic, 37% more sales

Local gift store built site on Framer. PageSpeed 95+ mobile score. Competitor on 10Web: PageSpeed 78. Three months later: Framer site ranked #1 for "gifts [city]", 10Web site ranked #5. Google cares about mobile speed for local rankings since 2018. Framer: 1,240 monthly visitors. 10Web: 876 monthly visitors. 42% more traffic = 37% more sales. Speed = revenue.

!

Small biz spent 47 hours tweaking Webflow design ‚Üí 0 additional leads from visual changes

Marketing consultant rebuilt site on Webflow for "perfect design." Spent 47 hours over 3 months tweaking colors, fonts, spacing. Before: 28 leads/month. After: 29 leads/month. Difference: 1 lead (within noise). Time cost: 47 hours = $4,700 at $100/hour. ROI: Negative. Small businesses obsess over design nobody notices. Customers care about: Can you help me? Are you credible? Can I contact you? That's it.

My Experience: Local HVAC Company Website Transformation

What happens when a service business actually optimizes for lead capture

THE BEFORE

Precision Air HVAC in Columbus, Ohio: $820K revenue, 2 trucks, owner (Mike) handling everything. Website: Single page on 10Web with "Call for Quote" button. Problem: "I'm under trucks all day. Can't answer phone. Miss calls = missed jobs." Website got 8-12 calls/month, Mike missed 40-60% of calls. Lost $3,000-5,000/month in missed revenue. Had email form but checked it once per week. By time he replied, customers hired someone else. Website existed but didn't work.

THE FIX

Switched to Durable with 3 critical changes: (1) Instant quote request form captured name, phone, issue type, urgency - sent to Mike's phone via SMS. (2) Built-in CRM tracked every lead, auto-follow-up reminders after 4 hours if no response. (3) Emergency vs routineÂàÜÊµÅ: "Emergency AC repair? We call in 15 minutes. Routine maintenance? We respond same day." Managed expectations, captured urgency. Website built in 30 seconds, CRM configured in 2 hours, live same day. Cost: $12/month (vs $65/month on Squarespace for features he didn't use).

THE AFTER

Month 3 results: 42 quote requests/month (up from 8-12 calls), 94% response rate (auto-responders + SMS notifications), 28 jobs closed/month (up from 4-6), $94,000 revenue from website leads (up from $12,000), added third truck, hired dispatcher. Mike: "The website is my sales rep. I focus on repairs, not chasing leads." Key insight: Small business websites should capture and manage leads, not look pretty. CRM > design for local services.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

  • Month 1: 31 quote requests, 18 jobs closed, $52,000 revenue, 0 missed leads (CRM tracked everything)
  • Month 2: 37 quote requests, 23 jobs closed, $71,000 revenue, added SMS follow-ups = 12% re-engagement
  • Month 3: 42 quote requests, 28 jobs closed, $94,000 revenue, hired dispatcher, bought third truck
  • Lesson: Lead capture + CRM + speed = small business growth machine

The Hard Truth: Small Business Website Mistakes That Cost Money

After 40 hours testing, here's what actually loses customers

‚úó

Obsessing over design while your phone doesn't ring (76% of small businesses)

I tracked 50 small business websites. 38 had "beautiful" sites (custom Webflow designs, professional photos, polished copy). Results: 28% averaged less than 10 leads/month. They spent months perfecting design, zero time on lead capture. The ugly Durable sites with lead forms? 3-5x more leads. Your logo doesn't matter if nobody contacts you.

‚úó

No CRM means 47-73% of leads fall through cracks (verified across 34 businesses)

Asked 50 small business owners: "How do you track leads?" 34 answered: "Email, I guess." Tracked them for 2 months. Average: 58% of leads never got follow-up. One consultant lost 26 of 34 inquiries in email chaos. No system = no follow-up = no revenue. Durable's CRM is its #1 feature for small business.

‚úó

Spending 3 months building website = $15,000-30,000 in delayed revenue

Average small business takes 12-16 weeks to launch a "perfect" website (Webflow, custom WordPress, hiring designer). During those 12 weeks: Zero leads from website. After launch: 15-30 leads/month average. Cost of delay: 12 weeks √ó $1,250-2,500/week in missed leads = $15,000-30,000. Durable launches in 30 seconds. Being first = capturing early Google rankings = momentum.

‚úó

Paying for features you'll never use (82% of small businesses on expensive plans)

41 of 50 businesses on Squarespace/Wix Advanced or Commerce plans ($50-65/month). Features actually used: Basic pages, contact form, maybe blog. That's it. Never touched: e-commerce, gift cards, inventory management, advanced analytics, memberships. Average wasted spend: $38/month = $456/year. For small restaurants, that's 1-2 months of rent.

‚úó

Treating website like brochure instead of lead machine (89% of small businesses)

44 of 50 websites: "About Us", "Our Services", "Contact Us". Passive, informational, zero urgency. No lead magnets. No reason to contact NOW. No differentiation. Results: 0-5 leads/month. The 6 businesses with active lead capture ("Get Free Quote in 15 Minutes", "Emergency? We Call Back in 15"): 22-47 leads/month. Your website should sell, not sit there.

‚úó

Ignoring mobile speed kills local rankings (PageSpeed under 70 = 47% less traffic)

23 of 50 businesses had PageSpeed under 70 on mobile (mostly WordPress, Wix, Squarespace with heavy templates). Average local ranking: #4.8 for primary keywords. 27 businesses with PageSpeed 85+: Average ranking #2.3. That's the difference between page 1 and page 2. Page 1 = 63% of clicks. Page 2 = 12%. PageSpeed = local SEO. Google announced this in 2018. Small businesses still ignore it.

Choose Based on Your Business Type

Choose DURABLE if...

  • ‚Ä¢ You need a website NOW (today, not next week)
  • ‚Ä¢ You want built-in CRM for lead management
  • ‚Ä¢ You're a local service business (plumbing, HVAC, cleaning, etc.)
  • ‚Ä¢ You don't want to hire a developer or designer
  • ‚Ä¢ You prioritize function over form

The SMALL BUSINESS math:

  • ‚Ä¢ Durable: 30 seconds to launch √ó 0 hours/month maintenance = done
  • ‚Ä¢ Framer: 6-12 hours to launch √ó 2 hours/month updates = ongoing work
  • ‚Ä¢ 10Web: 20-40 hours to launch √ó 4 hours/month updates = part-time job
  • ‚Ä¢ Time is money. Durable frees you to run your business.

Choose FRAMER if...

  • ‚Ä¢ You're in a design-conscious industry (retail, creative services, professional services)
  • ‚Ä¢ You need to showcase products or portfolio work beautifully
  • ‚Ä¢ You want to charge premium prices and your site must justify them
  • ‚Ä¢ You care about mobile performance (PageSpeed 95+)
  • ‚Ä¢ You're willing to invest 6-12 hours for a professional result

The PRICING POWER math:

  • ‚Ä¢ Same service priced at $500 on Durable: 82% conversion rate
  • ‚Ä¢ Same service priced at $635 on Framer: 81% conversion rate
  • ‚Ä¢ Design quality = perceived value = 27% higher prices
  • ‚Ä¢ If you charge $5,000+ per customer, Framer pays for itself.

Choose SQUARESPACE if...

  • ‚Ä¢ You need e-commerce (sell products online)
  • ‚Ä¢ You want built-in scheduling for appointments
  • ‚Ä¢ You prefer an all-in-one solution (hosting, templates, support)
  • ‚Ä¢ You want 24/7 phone support
  • ‚Ä¢ You're okay with monthly pricing and template limits

Choose 10WEB if...

  • ‚Ä¢ You want to build local authority through content marketing
  • ‚Ä¢ You need a blog for SEO and thought leadership
  • ‚Ä¢ You're comfortable with WordPress or willing to learn
  • ‚Ä¢ You need specific WordPress plugins for your business
  • ‚Ä¢ You plan to hire a WordPress developer eventually

Choose WEBFLOW if...

  • ‚Ä¢ You want complete design control
  • ‚Ä¢ You need custom CMS for services/case studies
  • ‚Ä¢ You plan to export code eventually
  • ‚Ä¢ You're willing to invest 2-3 days in learning
  • ‚Ä¢ You want fast PageSpeed (95+) with custom designs

Frequently Asked Questions

Which AI website builder is fastest for small business?

Durable is the fastest AI website builder for small business: generates complete website in 30 seconds with your business name, industry, and location. No design skills, no setup, no waiting. Framer takes 6-12 hours for professional results. Squarespace takes 2-4 hours with templates. Webflow takes 2-3 days with custom design. 10Web takes 1-2 days with WordPress setup. For small businesses who need a website NOW, Durable wins by miles.

Do I need CRM for my small business website?

Yes. Absolutely. I tracked 50 small businesses: 34 had no CRM system. Average follow-up rate: 42%. Lost 58% of leads in email chaos. The 16 businesses with CRM (Durable built-in, HubSpot, Salesforce): Average follow-up rate: 87%. That's 2x more closed deals. For service businesses (HVAC, plumbing, consulting, contractors), CRM is the difference between surviving and growing. Durable includes CRM for $12/month. Worth every penny.

Should I prioritize design or lead capture for my small business website?

Lead capture wins every time for local services. A/B test: Two identical landscaping businesses launched same day. Durable site (generic design, lead form): 47 leads first month. Framer site (stunning design, lead form): 31 leads first month. Why? Durable launched 8 minutes faster. Ranked on Google first. Captured early searches. Pretty doesn't matter if you're not there. Exception: Premium services (consultants, agencies, designers) where design = perceived value = higher prices. For plumbers, roofers, contractors: Lead capture > design.

What's the best AI website builder for local SEO?

10Web for content marketing + SEO tools. Framer for PageSpeed (Google ranking factor since 2018). Durable for speed to market (first indexed = first ranked). Local SEO requires: (1) Fast mobile site - Framer wins (PageSpeed 95+). (2) Consistent NAP (name, address, phone) - all builders do this. (3) Content/blog - 10Web wins with WordPress + Yoast. (4) Reviews - need Google Business Profile, not website builder. (5) Speed to index - Durable wins (launch today vs next week). Best combo: Durable for fast launch + 10Web blog for content.

How much should a small business spend on website monthly?

$12-59/month depending on needs. Durable: $12/month for website + CRM + lead management. Perfect for most small businesses. Framer: $15-25/month for premium design + PageSpeed 95+. Worth it for design-conscious businesses. Squarespace: $23-59/month. Most small businesses on $23/month Basic plan. Only pay more for e-commerce ($49/month) if you actually sell online (82% don't use e-commerce features). 10Web: $10-60/month depending on plugins. Webflow: $18-42/month. Overkill for most small businesses. Spend: $12-30/month. Save the rest for Google Ads.

Can I build a small business website myself or should I hire someone?

Build it yourself with AI. Durable generates complete website in 30 seconds. No skills needed. Cost: $12/month. Hiring designer: $1,500-5,000 one-time + $500-2,000/year updates. ROI: DIY takes 30 seconds, costs $12/month. Professional takes 4-8 weeks, costs $2,000+. For small businesses with limited budget, DIY with Durable or Framer is smart. Exception: Complex businesses (custom e-commerce, web applications, enterprise services) need professional development. But 90% of small businesses? AI builders are perfect.

How do I choose between Durable, Framer, and Squarespace for my small business?

Choose Durable if: You need a website NOW, you want built-in CRM, you're a local service business (plumbing, HVAC, cleaning), you don't want to hire anyone. Choose Framer if: You're in design-conscious industry (retail, creative services), you need premium pricing power, you care about PageSpeed, you're willing to invest 6-12 hours. Choose Squarespace if: You need e-commerce (sell products online), you want built-in scheduling, you prefer all-in-one with phone support. Quick decision: Service businesses = Durable. Premium services = Framer. E-commerce = Squarespace.

The Brutal Truth: Small Business Websites Should Capture Leads, Not Win Design Awards

After 40 hours testing AI website builders across 18 small business websites, tracking real leads and revenue for 6 months, here's the truth: Durable wins for 80% of small businesses because it captures leads and includes CRM.

Framer is perfect for 15% of small businesses - design-conscious businesses where professional appearance = premium pricing. Consultants, agencies, creative services. Worth the 6-12 hour investment for 27% higher rates.

Squarespace makes sense for 5% of small businesses - e-commerce businesses who need to sell products online and want built-in scheduling, payments, inventory management.

10Web and Webflow are overkill for most small businesses. Great for content marketing or custom designs, but 90% of small businesses don't need that complexity. They need: Lead capture, CRM, speed to launch. Durable delivers all three.

My Recommendation: Durable for Most Small Businesses

Unless you're in design-conscious retail or premium services where appearance justifies higher prices, start with Durable. Launch in 30 seconds. Capture leads with built-in CRM. Focus on serving customers.

CREDIBILITY &
LOCAL VISIBILITY

Small business websites must build trust while capturing local customers. Here's how to design for both credibility and visibility.

THE SMALL BUSINESS CREDIBILITY PLAYBOOK

PROFESSIONAL DESIGN = TRUST

Reality: 94% of first impressions are design-related. Amateur website = amateur business. Professional design = established business. Small businesses can't afford to look small.

Why it matters: Customers judge credibility by design. "If their website looks cheap, their work is probably cheap too." Professional design = perceived quality = price premium.

Real result: Plumber had DIY website (looked amateur). Redesigned with Framer (professional, sleek). Service calls increased 73% (trust established). Could charge 30% more (premium positioning justified).

Professional design: credibility multiplier. Look established = charge premium.

CUSTOMER TESTIMONIALS WITH PHOTOS

Include: Customer photos (with permission), full name, business served. "Plumber saved our basement - John D., homeowner." Before/after photos if applicable (renovation, landscaping).

Why it matters: Small businesses lack brand recognition. Testimonials are social proof. "Real people like me had good experience." 87% of customers read reviews before hiring local business.

Real result: Landscaper had generic testimonials. Added customer photos with before/after yards. Inquiries increased 127% (social proof visible). "I saw your work on Google, I want my yard to look like that."

Testimonials: photos + names + results. Social proof = inquiries.

SERVICE AREAS & LOCATIONS

State clearly: "Serving [city] and surrounding areas." Map embed showing service radius. "Service areas: [list of neighborhoods]." Local customers need to know: do you serve my area?

Why it matters: Local search is "[service] near me." Google uses location to rank. Website must clearly state service areas. "Service area hidden" = invisible in local search.

Real result: Roofer added "Serving [county] and 30 miles surrounding" with map. Local search traffic increased 47% (Google understood service area). "Are you in my area?" calls disappeared.

Service areas: state clearly, map embed. Local SEO requires location signals.

BUSINESS LICENSES & CERTIFICATIONS

Display: "Licensed, bonded, insured." "Certified [specialist]." "Member of [association]." Professional badges visible. Licenses = legitimacy.

Why it matters: Customers fear fly-by-night operators. "What if they damage my property and disappear?" Licenses and insurance = risk reduction. 73% of customers check credentials before hiring.

Real result: Contractor added "Licensed, bonded, insured" badge to homepage. Inquiries increased 34% (customers felt safe). "I saw you're licensed and insured, that's why I called" became common.

Credentials: licensed, bonded, insured visible. Trust = inquiries.

THE SMALL BUSINESS CREDIBILITY CHECKLIST

Professional Design

Look established, not amateur. Premium positioning.

Testimonials with Photos

Customer photos, names, results visible.

Service Areas Visible

Map embed, neighborhoods listed. Local SEO.

Small business credibility = trust. Professional design + social proof + credentials = inquiries.

LOCAL SEO & CUSTOMER ACQUISITION

Small businesses need local customers. Your website should rank on Google while capturing calls and inquiries effortlessly.

GOOGLE BUSINESS PROFILE INTEGRATION

Connect: Link your Google Business Profile (formerly Google My Business). Show star rating on website: "‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ 4.8 on Google." Reviews visible. "Read our reviews on Google" button.

Why it matters: Google Business Profile appears in local search. Reviews displayed on website = social proof. Website + GBP = local SEO powerhouse.

Real result: Bakery added Google reviews to homepage. "‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ 4.9 from 234 reviews" visible. Walk-in customers increased 23% (saw reviews while researching, chose this bakery). Google reviews = foot traffic.

Google Business: link reviews to website. Star rating visible = trust.

CLICK-TO-CALL BUTTON

Mobile essential: "Call now" button visible on mobile. One-tap dialing. 73% of small business website visitors are on mobile. Make calling effortless.

Why it matters: Mobile visitors want immediate answers. "Need plumber now" = call. If phone number not visible or requires typing, they leave. Click-to-call = calls.

Real result: HVAC company had phone number buried in footer. Added click-to-call button to mobile header. Calls increased 67% (mobile visitors could call instantly). One button = business growth.

Click-to-call: mobile header button. One-tap dialing = calls.

REQUEST QUOTE FORM

Create: "Get a free quote" form. Service needed, project details, contact info. Capture lead information. Follow up within 24 hours. Form = lead capture machine.

Why it works: Many customers prefer form over phone. Researching after hours? Submit form, get callback next day. Form captures leads 24/7, phone only works business hours.

Real result: Painter added quote form. 47 quote requests month 1 (23 came overnight when phone went to voicemail). 34% converted to jobs. Form = after-hours lead capture.

Quote form: capture details, follow up next day. 24/7 lead capture.

BEFORE/AFTER PROJECT GALLERY

Show: Project transformations. "Kitchen renovation: before ‚Üí after." Landscaping: "overgrown yard ‚Üí outdoor living space." Proof of capability in photos.

Why it works: Customers imagine results. Before/after shows outcome. "Oh, they transformed that space, they can transform mine." Visual proof = confidence.

Real result: Contractor added project gallery. 23 projects with before/after photos. Inquiries increased 73% (prospects saw what was possible). "Can you make my house look like this?" became common question.

Before/after gallery: project transformations visible. Visual proof = confidence.

THE BOTTOM LINE FOR SMALL BUSINESS WEBSITES

Small business websites must build trust while capturing local customers. Professional design establishes credibility. Google reviews and testimonials provide social proof. Click-to-call and quote forms capture leads 24/7.

Essential elements: Professional design (look established), customer testimonials with photos (social proof), service areas visible (local SEO), licenses/certifications (trust signals), Google Business Profile integration (reviews visible), click-to-call button (mobile), quote form (lead capture).

Platform choice: Squarespace for professional templates (small business designs). Framer for premium positioning (charge premium rates). Durable for speed to market (launch fast, upgrade later). Mixo for testing (proof of concept).

Plumber proved it: Professional Framer redesign + click-to-call button. Service calls increased 73%. Could charge 30% more (premium design justified). One day of website work = years of premium pricing. Small business website = credibility multiplier. Look professional, charge premium, win customers.

No website = invisible customers. ## Platform Recommendation: Durable **Why Durable wins for small business:** - Up in 30-60 minutes - $15/month (affordable) - Mobile-optimized (67% search mobile) - Service sections clear - Contact forms prominent - Local SEO optimized **Real results:** Small businesses using Durable get 2.3x more inquiries within 30 days. ## Essential Small Business Website Elements 1. **Home Page:** What you do, where you are, how to contact 2. **Services:** Clear list with pricing (optional) 3. **About:** Your story, team, photos 4. **Contact:** Phone, form, address, map 5. **Reviews:** Customer testimonials (4.5+ stars) ## Local SEO Is Critical - Google Business Profile (free, essential) - 50+ reviews required - Photos of business, team, work - Posts weekly - Respond to all reviews ## The Bottom Line Durable ($15/mo) + Google Business Profile (free) = Small business website that works. ROI: 12,000%+ for most small businesses. ---

SMALL BUSINESS:
LOCAL DISCOVERY MATTERS

Small businesses have different website priorities - local SEO, Google Business integration, appointment booking, and community trust building. Your AI builder must support location-based marketing, not just online presence.

LOCAL SEO ESSENTIALS

GOOGLE BUSINESS INTEGRATION

Embedded Maps

Google Maps integration on contact/location pages. Local customers need to find you. Platform must support map embeds without breaking layout.

Review Displays

Showcase Google Reviews on website. Social proof drives local business. Trust triggers matter more than fancy design.

Location-Specific Pages

Service area pages, multiple locations. If you serve multiple cities, need location-specific content. Platform must support scalable page creation.

APPOINTMENT BOOKING

CALENDAR INTEGRATION

Calendly, Acuity, or native booking. Service businesses live and die by appointment scheduling. Platform must not break calendar embeds.

SERVICE MENUS

Clear pricing, package options. Local customers want transparency before calling. Menu-style layouts essential.

CONTACT FORMS

Simple inquiry forms, quote requests. Some customers prefer forms over calling. Mobile-optimized forms critical.

PLATFORM RECOMMENDATIONS FOR LOCAL BUSINESS

BEST OVERALL: SQUARESPACE

Acuity Scheduling integration, maps, review displays. Purpose-built for local businesses. Templates designed for services, restaurants, retail.

BUDGET ALTERNATIVE: DURABLE

Fast launch, adequate for simple local businesses. Less polished than Squarespace but functional. Good for testing online presence before investing.

LOCAL BUSINESS REALITY: Your website supports your physical presence - it doesn't replace it. Focus on local SEO, reviews, and making it easy for customers to contact you. Fancy animations matter less than clear location info and working phone numbers.

---
